title: East Riding of Yorkshire Heritage Walk Route

images.title: Trish Steel [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bempton Cliffs. Whether viewed from land or from the sea, Bempton Cliffs is a spectacle, particularly so during the breeding season when vast numbers of seabirds are present.

images.title: Dr Patty McAlpin / Thornwick Nab and Great Thornwick Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Thornwick Nab and Great Thornwick Bay. Taken from the coastal path around High Holme, this shows Thornwick Nab, with its arch cut into the Chalk, jutting out to sea and stunning Great Thornwick Bay. Eventually the arch will collapse, leaving a pillar (stack) of chalk cut off from the rest of the headland. The beach shingle is predominantly of local flint and chalk, but there are numerous erratic rocks and pebbles released from the boulder clay (which overlies the Chalk) which has fallen/slipped on to the beach and been broken up by the sea. Large boulders of various types are also scattered over the beach.

images.title: Dr Patty McAlpin / Flamborough Head, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The coastline at Flamborough Head, renowned for its dazzling white chalk cliffs and stacks, with the Fog Signal Station situated on the most easterly point of the headland.

images.title: Driffield Navigation by Paul Harrop, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Driffield Navigation Canal

images.title: Mat Fascione / North Sands at Bridlington
images.caption: North Sands at Bridlington

images.title: David Wright / The Hessle Foreshore
images.caption: The Hessle Foreshore near the start of the walk. Photo taken just West of the Humber bridge looking upstream.

images.title: Filey beach by Pauline E, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Filey beach at the northern end of the walk.

description: Follow the East Riding Heritage Way from the Humber Bridge to Filey on this trail through the East Yorkshire countryside. The walk starts with a section along the Humber Estaury from Hessle and heads to Beverley, with its wonderful minster. You continue to Driffield where there is a lovely waterside section along the Driffield Canal. The next stage then takes you to the coast and the seaside resort of Bridlington. The rest of the route then follows the spectacular East Yorkshire coastline, passing Bempton Cliffs with its huge seabird colonies, the lighthouse at Flamborough Head (video below) and the interesting cliff arch at Thornwick Bay before finishing at Filey.
